description: From Middle English bist, beest, best, from Old English bist ("(thou) art"; second person singular of bēon (“to be”)), from Proto-Germanic *biusi (“(thou) art”), equivalent to be +‎ -est. Cognate with West Frisian bist (“(thou) art”), Low German büst (“(thou) art”), German bist (“(thou) art”).

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, Black Country, Bristol, West Country, Northern England) Used to form the second person singular of be.
examples: Thee bist rayther too much a feelosofer, I be afeard, for me.
